overview_of_class:
COURSE DESCRIPTION / Engineering elements of water supply and pollution abatement. Water quality standards, water and wastewater treatment processes and the management of receiving waters to control pollution.

COURSE OBJECTIVES / The course is designed to introduce juniors and seniors in civil or environmental engineering to theory of water and wastewater treatment processes and their design. Municipal and industrial applications and behavior of pollutants in the environment complement the major goal.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
COURSE DESCRIPTION / Engineering elements of water supply and pollution abatement. Water quality standards, water and wastewater treatment processes and the management of receiving waters to control pollution.

COURSE OBJECTIVES / The course is designed to introduce juniors and seniors in civil or environmental engineering to theory of water and wastewater treatment processes and their design. Municipal and industrial applications and behavior of pollutants in the environment complement the major goal.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: MECH_ENG 241 (Fluid!Mechanics!I) and CIV_ENV 260 (Fundamentals of Environmental!Engineering); CIV_ENV 340 recommended (Fluid!MechanicsII).

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students successfully completing the course will be able to:

1. Examine factors involved in water demand and wastewater aggregate and differential yields in a community settings;

2. Determine distribution of flows, safe yield / capacity of retention facilities in water supply and distribution or stormwater control as part of water quantity management;

3. Compute basic flow and pipe sizing for sewerage / stormwater example systems; using hydraulic and energy grade lines and calculate pumping and hydraulic constraints for pressure supply systems;

4 Develop flowsheets for treating water and wastewater to meet physical, chemical and biological design parameters;

5. Using energy and mass conservation balances, size heat and mass transfer devices in water and wastewater treatment;

6. Utilize tracer curves and dispersion model to determine non ideal mixing effects;

7. Compute doses of chemicals to reduce hardness, turbidity and microbials expressed in chemical, e.g. meq/l and practical lb / MG or lb / day units;

8. Analyze the performance (including unit sizing) of common physical, chemical, and biological unit processes

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: CLASS SCHEDULE / Four 1-hr lecture/discussions per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Homework? Six homework assignments - 30%
? Two exams - 40%
? Group project that will involve the conceptual design and/or analysis of a water resources solution - 25% : 15% report + 7.5% presentation + 2.5% teamwork (peer evaluation)
? Participation (class attendance and discussion) - 5%
